title: Training
description: Requirements for comprehensive food safety training programs including hygiene training, illness reporting procedures, and documentation of training and corrective actions

requirements.text: Is there a food safety hygiene training program covering new and existing workers and are there records of these training events?
mandatoryStatements: Food safety hygiene training program is documented
Program covers personal hygiene requirements
Training is provided to all new workers before starting work
Existing workers receive annual refresher training at minimum
Training is provided in language(s) understood by workers
Training records document date, attendees, topics, and trainer
Training includes handwashing, illness reporting, hygiene rules, and contamination prevention
Training effectiveness is assessed
Workers demonstrate understanding of food safety hygiene requirements
requirements.verificationExpectations: Quarterly audit of training records for completeness, annual assessment of training effectiveness
requirements.monitoringExpectations: Immediate training of new workers, annual refresher training for all workers, ongoing verification of hygiene compliance

requirements.text: Are there written and communicated procedures in place that require food handlers to report any cuts or grazes and/or if they are suffering from any illnesses that might be a contamination risk to the products being produced, and return to work requirements? (In countries with health privacy/confidentiality laws, e.g., USA, auditors can check procedure/policy but not actual records).
mandatoryStatements: Written procedure requires workers to report illnesses and injuries
Procedure specifies reportable illnesses (diarrhea, vomiting, jaundice, fever with sore throat, infected wounds, etc.)
Procedure requires reporting of cuts, grazes, and open wounds
Return to work criteria are defined
Procedure is communicated to all food handlers during orientation and training
Reporting process is confidential where required by law
Management response to reports is defined (evaluation, exclusion, restriction, medical clearance)
Workers understand obligation to report without fear of retaliation
Procedure is posted in appropriate locations
requirements.verificationExpectations: Annual review of illness reporting procedure, verification during training observations
requirements.monitoringExpectations: Daily pre-work health checks where appropriate, immediate management response to illness reports

requirements.text: Are there worker food safety non-conformance records and associated corrective actions (including retraining records)?
mandatoryStatements: System exists to document worker food safety violations
Non-conformances are documented with date, worker, and specific violation
Corrective actions are documented for each non-conformance
Retraining is provided when violations indicate lack of understanding
Repeat violations result in escalating corrective actions
Serious violations result in immediate action (removal from food handling, etc.)
Records demonstrate accountability and continuous improvement
Non-conformance trends are analyzed to identify systemic issues
requirements.verificationExpectations: Quarterly review of non-conformance records and corrective action effectiveness
requirements.monitoringExpectations: Immediate documentation of violations, timely corrective actions including retraining within 7 days

capaInject: If training program incomplete or records inadequate: develop/update training program within 14 days, train all workers within 30 days, maintain complete records going forward
If illness reporting procedure not in place or not communicated: develop procedure immediately, train all workers within 7 days, post signage
If non-conformances not documented or corrective actions not taken: implement documentation system immediately, address all outstanding violations, retrain workers as needed
traceabilityInject: Training records must be traceable to specific employees, training dates, topics, and trainers
Illness reporting procedures must be traceable to specific communications and training events
Non-conformance records must be traceable to specific workers, violations, dates, and corrective actions
